messages.subject: Higo
messages.msgSnippet: Let s not rule out later Nishigaki either as it was influenced by the Edo Higo group (Torigoye, Tsuba An Aesthetic Study).  I tend to have a problem with metal
messages.messageBody:
Let's not rule out later Nishigaki either as it was influenced by the
Edo Higo group (Torigoye, Tsuba An Aesthetic Study). I tend to have a
problem with metal quality as a parameter because as you progress into
the later Edo period factory plate was presumably used in greater
quantity. The sharpness of the sukashi and ornateness of the inlay
influence my feeling toward Edo Higo.
As far as fare market value, who knows? If in doubt I'd take it to
Tampa and show it around. It's only a few weeks off anyway (unreal,
huh) and it's far better than Ebay! Later.

messages.subject: Higo
messages.msgSnippet: Hey Curran -- my gut hunch is either Nakane Heihachiro or Edo Higo, most prob Nakane.  The example on Andy Quirts site and this one have the same indentations
messages.messageBody:
Hey Curran -- my gut hunch is either Nakane Heihachiro or Edo Higo,
most prob Nakane. The example on Andy Quirts site and this one have
the same indentations about the nakagoana (I am not certain if tagane
mei is appropriate here -- Jim would know on this -- I've seen this on
other Higo pieces also). You know I've seen examples from some of the
other Higo schools with this 'look' so it's sort of a guess.

From what I've heard the Higo Taikan has a lot of questionable
attributions, but then it seems as time goes on that's what you here
about most of the older reference books. I get the feeling there is a
move into orthodoxy going on in the field -- Sasano, Torigoye, and
other explorationists being questioned in absentia. Hmmmm, always
interesting. I have to wonder at times if not being able to read the
Japanese texts is a curse or a blessing in disguise as it forces us to
think for ourselves (heretics all) instead of towing the party line.
Well, I guess I've still got that 60's in me! Later.
